sen.j: 松姫（まつひめ、永禄4年（1561年） - 元和 (日本)2年4月16日 (旧暦)（1616年5月31日））は、戦国大名の武田信玄の五女。
sen.e: Princess Matsu (1561 - May 31, 1616) was the fifth daughter of the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) Shingen TAKEDA.
Princess Matsu (1561 - May 31, 1616) was the fifth daughter of the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period [period of Warring States]) Shingen TAKEDA.
sen.cmt: 説明訳括弧を補足しました。
sen.e: Princess Matsu (1561 - May 31, 1616) was the fifth daughter of the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period [period of Warring States]) Shingen TAKEDA.

sen.j: 母は側室油川夫人、仁科盛信の同母妹。
sen.e: Her mother was a concubine Fujin ARAKAWA, and she was a younger sister of Morinobu NISHINA.
Her mother was a concubine Aburakawafujin, and she was a younger sister of Morinobu NISHINA.
Her mother was a concubine Aburakawafujin, and she was a younger sister of Morinobu NISHINA.

sen.j: 出家後は信松尼。
sen.e: She was called Shinshoni after becoming a nun.
She was called Shinshoni after becoming a nun.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: She was called Shinshoni after becoming a nun.

sen.j: 甲斐の生まれ。
sen.e: She was born in Kai.
She was born in Kai.
She was born in Kai.

sen.j: 永禄10年（1567年）、7歳の時に織田信長の嫡男織田信忠（11歳）との婚約が成立する。
sen.e: In 1567, at age 7, she became engaged to Nobutada ODA (11), an heir of Nobunaga ODA.
In 1567, at age 7, she became engaged to Nobutada ODA (11), an heir of Nobunaga ODA.
In 1567, at age 7, she became engaged to Nobutada ODA (11), an heir of Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 松姫と信忠は実際に会ったことはなく、手紙のやりとりをして過ごし、両者は次第に精神的な繋がりが出来たという。
sen.e: Princess Matsu and Nobutada had not actually seen each other in person, but spent time exchanging mail, and eventually had a spiritual connection.
Princess Matsu and Nobutada had not actually seen each other in person, but spent time exchanging mail, and eventually had a spiritual connection.
Princess Matsu and Nobutada had not actually seen each other in person, but spent time exchanging mail, and eventually had a spiritual connection.

sen.j: なお、武田家において形式上は「信忠正室を預かる」として扱かわれ、新館御料人と呼ばれた。
sen.e: She stayed with the Takeda family and was formally treated as "the entrusted lawful wife of Nobutada," and was called Niitachi goryonin.
She stayed with the Takeda family and was formally treated as 'the entrusted lawful wife of Nobutada,' and was called Niitachi goryonin.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: She stayed with the Takeda family and was formally treated as 'the entrusted lawful wife of Nobutada,' and was called Niitachi goryonin.

sen.j: 元亀3年（1572年）、武田信玄が西上を開始すると、徳川家康との間で三方ヶ原の戦いが起こった。
sen.e: In 1572, when Shingen Takeda started to conquer westward, the Battle of Mikatagahara broke out against Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1572, when Shingen TAKEDA started to conquer westward, the Battle of Mikatagahara broke out against Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
In 1572, when Shingen TAKEDA started to conquer westward, the Battle of Mikatagahara broke out against Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 信長が徳川に援軍を送ったことから、武田・織田両家は手切れとなり、松姫（11歳）との婚約も解消される。
sen.e: Because Nobunaga sent reinforcement to Tokugawa, the relation between the Takeda and Oda families broke and the engagement to Princess Matsu (11) was also canceled.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because Nobunaga sent reinforcement to Tokugawa, the relation between the Takeda and Oda families broke and the engagement to Princess Matsu (11) was also canceled.
Because Nobunaga sent reinforcement to Tokugawa, the relation between the Takeda and Oda families broke and the engagement to Princess Matsu (11) was also canceled.

sen.j: 天正元年（1573年）、武田信玄が没する。
sen.e: In 1573, Shingen Takeda deceased..
In 1573, Shingen TAKEDA deceased.
sen.cmt: TAKEDA大文字にしました。不要なピリオドを削除しました。
sen.e: In 1573, Shingen TAKEDA deceased.

sen.j: 兄である仁科盛信の庇護のもと、高遠城の城下の館に移る。
sen.e: She moved to a house in the castle town of Takato-jo Castle under the patronage of her brother Morinobu Nishina.
She moved to a house in the castle town of Takato-jo Castle under the patronage of her brother Morinobu NISHINA.
She moved to a house in the castle town of Takato-jo Castle under the patronage of her brother Morinobu NISHINA.

sen.j: 天正8年（1580年）、盛信が高遠城主となる。
sen.e: In 1580, Morinobu became the lord of Takato-jo Castle.
In 1580, Morinobu became the lord of Takato-jo Castle.
In 1580, Morinobu became the lord of Takato-jo Castle.

tit.j: 武田氏滅亡と織田信忠の死
tit.e: the fall of the Takeda family and death of Nobutada Oda
The fall of the Takeda family and death of Nobutada ODA
tit.cmt: The大文字にしました。ODA大文字にしました。
tit.e: The fall of the Takeda family and death of Nobutada ODA

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）、かつての婚約者であった織田信忠を総大将とする織田軍の武田征伐を避ける為、仁科盛信の娘・小督姫ら3人の姫を連れて、武田旧臣が多く住む武州多摩郡恩方（現・東京都八王子市）へ向かい、古刹・金照庵（現・八王子市上恩方町）に入る。
sen.e: In 1582, to avoid subjugation of Takeda by the Oda army led by her former fiance, the supreme commander Nobutada Oda, she went to Ongata, Tama county, Bushu (Hachioji City, Tokyo) where many old retainers of the Takeda clan lived to live in kosatsu Kinsho-an (ancient temple, Kinsho-an Retreat) (located in Kamiongata-machi, Hachioji City).

In 1582, to avoid subjugation of Takeda by the Oda army led by her former fiance, the supreme commander Nobutada ODA, she went to Ongata, Tama County, Bushu (Hachioji City, Tokyo) where many old retainers of the Takeda clan lived to live in kosatsu Kinsho-an (ancient temple, Kinsho-an Retreat) (located in Kamiongata-machi, Hachioji City).
sen.cmt: ODA大文字にしました。County大文字にしました。不要なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: In 1582, to avoid subjugation of Takeda by the Oda army led by her former fiance, the supreme commander Nobutada ODA, she went to Ongata, Tama County, Bushu (Hachioji City, Tokyo) where many old retainers of the Takeda clan lived to live in kosatsu Kinsho-an (ancient temple, Kinsho-an Retreat) (located in Kamiongata-machi, Hachioji City).

sen.j: 3月1日、岐阜城を進発した織田信忠率いる織田軍3万が高遠城を包囲する。
sen.e: On April 3, The Oda army lead by Nobutada Oda who departed for the front from Gifu-jo Castle besieged Takato-jo Castle.
On April 3, the Oda army lead by Nobutada ODA who departed for the front from Gifu-jo Castle besieged Takato-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: the小文字にしました。ODA大文字にしました。
sen.e: On April 3, the Oda army lead by Nobutada ODA who departed for the front from Gifu-jo Castle besieged Takato-jo Castle.

sen.j: 信忠は降伏を勧告するも仁科盛信はこれを拒絶。
sen.e: Nobutada recommended surrender, but Morinobu Nishina refused it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Nobutada recommended surrender, but Morinobu NISHINA refused it.
Nobutada recommended surrender, but Morinobu NISHINA refused it.

sen.j: 信忠は総攻撃を開始し、激戦の末ついに盛信は自刃する（武田征伐）。
sen.e: Nobutada started all-out assault, and after a fierce battle, Morinobu finally committed suicide (subjugation of Takeda).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Nobutada started all-out assault, and after a fierce battle, Morinobu finally committed suicide (subjugation of Takeda).
Nobutada started all-out assault, and after a fierce battle, Morinobu finally committed suicide (subjugation of Takeda).

sen.j: 新府城に火を放ち逃亡した武田勝頼を追撃する信忠は、3月7日に甲府へ入り本陣を置く。
sen.e: Nobutada, chasing Katsuyori TAKEDA who set fire to Shinpu-jo Castle, entered Kofu on April 9 and put the headquarters.
Nobutada, chasing Katsuyori TAKEDA who set fire to Shinpu-jo Castle, entered Kofu on April 9 and put the headquarters.
Nobutada, chasing Katsuyori TAKEDA who set fire to Shinpu-jo Castle, entered Kofu on April 9 and put the headquarters.

sen.j: 3月11日、信忠の軍監・滝川一益に追い詰められた武田勝頼・武田信勝父子らは天目山の田野で自刃し、武田氏甲斐武田氏は滅亡した（天目山の戦い）。
sen.e: On April 13, Katsuyori Takeda and his son Nobukatsu TAKEDA and others, driven into a corner by Kazumasu TAKIGAWA, the Assistant Deputy General of Nobutada, committed suicide in Tano in Tenmoku-zan Mountain, and the Takeda clan and the Kai-Takeda clan fell (Battle of Tenmoku-zan).

On April 13, Katsuyori TAKEDA and his son Nobukatsu TAKEDA and others, driven into a corner by Kazumasu TAKIGAWA, the Assistant Deputy General of Nobutada, committed suicide in Tano in Tenmoku-zan Mountain, and the Takeda clan and the Kai-Takeda clan fell (Battle of Tenmoku-zan).

On April 13, Katsuyori TAKEDA and his son Nobukatsu TAKEDA and others, driven into a corner by Kazumasu TAKIGAWA, the Assistant Deputy General of Nobutada, committed suicide in Tano in Tenmoku-zan Mountain, and the Takeda clan and the Kai-Takeda clan fell (Battle of Tenmoku-zan).

sen.j: 武田征伐後、八王子に落ち延びていた松姫のもとに織田信忠から迎えの使者が訪れる。
sen.e: After subjugation of Takeda, an envoy of Nobutada Oda visited Princess Matsu who escaped to Hachioji to bring her back.
After subjugation of Takeda, an envoy of Nobutada ODA visited Princess Matsu who escaped to Hachioji to bring her back.
After subjugation of Takeda, an envoy of Nobutada ODA visited Princess Matsu who escaped to Hachioji to bring her back.

sen.j: 6月2日、松姫が信忠に会いに行く道中にて本能寺の変が勃発し、信忠は二条御所で明智光秀を迎え討ち明智軍を3度撃退する。
sen.e: On July 1, when Princess Matsu was on a journey to see Nobutada, the Honnoji Incident broke out, and Nobutada attacked Mitsuhide AKECHI at Nijo-gosho Palace and beat the Akechi army three times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On July 1, when Princess Matsu was on a journey to see Nobutada, the Honnoji Incident broke out, and Nobutada attacked Mitsuhide AKECHI at Nijo-gosho Palace and beat the Akechi army three times.
On July 1, when Princess Matsu was on a journey to see Nobutada, the Honnoji Incident broke out, and Nobutada attacked Mitsuhide AKECHI at Nijo-gosho Palace and beat the Akechi army three times.

sen.j: しかし、衆寡敵せず自刃して果てる（一部の史料には信忠の子・織田秀信の生母は実は松姫だったとするものもあるが、生前に松姫と信忠が会ったという可能性すら低く、何らかの誤りと考えられている）。
sen.e: However, he was hopelessly outnumbered and committed suicide (According to some historical materials, the real mother of Nobutada's child Hidenobu ODA was actually Princess Matsu, but even the possibility that Princess Matsu and Nobutada met while they were alive is low, and it is considered to be some mistake).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, he was hopelessly outnumbered and committed suicide (according to some historical materials, the real mother of Nobutada's child Hidenobu ODA was actually Princess Matsu, but even the possibility that Princess Matsu and Nobutada met while they were alive is low, and it is considered to be some mistake).

However, he was hopelessly outnumbered and committed suicide (according to some historical materials, the real mother of Nobutada's child Hidenobu ODA was actually Princess Matsu, but even the possibility that Princess Matsu and Nobutada met while they were alive is low, and it is considered to be some mistake).

sen.j: 同年秋、22歳で心源院（現・八王子市下恩方町）に移り、出家した。
sen.e: In autumn of the same year, she moved to Shingen-in Temple (Shimoongata-machi, Hachioji City) when she was 22, and became a nun.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In autumn of the same year, she moved to Shingen-in Temple (Shimoongata-machi, Hachioji City) when she was 22, and became a nun.
In autumn of the same year, she moved to Shingen-in Temple (Shimoongata-machi, Hachioji City) when she was 22, and became a nun.

sen.j: 信松尼と称し、武田一族とともに信忠の冥福を祈ったという。
sen.e: She called herself Shinshoni and they say that she prayed for the soul of Nobutada as well as the Takeda family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She called herself Shinshoni and they say that she prayed for the soul of Nobutada as well as the Takeda family.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: She called herself Shinshoni and they say that she prayed for the soul of Nobutada as well as the Takeda family.

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年）八王子・御所水（現・八王子市台町）のあばら家に移り住む。
sen.e: In 1590, she moved to a hut in Goshomizu, Hachioji (present Dai-machi, Hachioji City).
In 1590, she moved to a hut in Goshomizu, Hachioji (present Dai-machi, Hachioji City).
In 1590, she moved to a hut in Goshomizu, Hachioji (present Dai-machi, Hachioji City).

sen.j: 尼としての生活の傍ら、寺子屋で近所の子供たちに読み書きを教え、蚕を育て、織物を作り得た収入で、3人の姫を養育する日々だったという。
sen.e: While living as a nun, it is said that she taught reading and writing to local children in a Terakoya (temple elementary school in the Edo period), did sericulture, and weaved cloth to earn money to raise her three princesses.

While living as a nun, it is said that she taught reading and writing to local children in a Terakoya (temple elementary school in the Edo period), did sericulture, and weaved cloth to earn money to raise her three princesses.

While living as a nun, it is said that she taught reading and writing to local children in a Terakoya (temple elementary school in the Edo period), did sericulture, and weaved cloth to earn money to raise her three princesses.

sen.j: 武田家臣であり、当時は江戸幕府代官頭の大久保長安は、信松尼のために草庵を作るなど支援をしたという。
sen.e: Nagayasu OKUBO, who used to be a vassals of Takeda family and then daikangashira (head of Edo-period prefectural governor (magistrate, bailiff)) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), is said to have helped Shinshoni including building a thatched hut for her.

Nagayasu OKUBO, who used to be a vassals of Takeda family and then daikangashira (the head of feudal government) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), is said to have helped Shinshoni including building a thatched hut for her.
sen.cmt: the head of feudal government に訂正しました。
sen.e: Nagayasu OKUBO, who used to be a vassals of Takeda family and then daikangashira (the head of feudal government) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), is said to have helped Shinshoni including building a thatched hut for her.

sen.j: また、武田家の旧臣の多くからなる八王子千人同心たちの心の支えともなったという。
sen.e: In addition, it is said that she served as spiritual support of Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji) composed of many of the old retainers of the Takeda clan.
In addition, it is said that she served as spiritual support of Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji) composed of many of the old retainers of the Takeda clan.
In addition, it is said that she served as spiritual support of Hachioji Sennin Doshin (junior officials in Hachioji) composed of many of the old retainers of the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)2年（1616年）、没する。
sen.e: She died in 1616.
She died in 1616.
She died in 1616.

sen.j: 享年56。
sen.e: Her age at death was 56.
Her age at death was 56.
Her age at death was 56.

sen.j: 草庵は現在の信松院である。
sen.e: Her thatched hut is present Shinsho-in Temple.
Her thatched hut is present Shinsho-in Temple.
Her thatched hut is present Shinsho-in Temple.

sen.j: 松姫の母油川夫人は甲州一の美女として名高く、松姫自身も同母姉妹である菊姫 (上杉景勝正室)と共に美貌で有名であった。
sen.e: Princess Matsu's mother Fujin Arakawa was famous as the most beautiful woman in Koshu, and Princess Matsu herself was also famous for her beauty along with her sister Princess Kiku (lawful wife of Kagekatsu UESUGI).

Princess Matsu's mother Aburakawafujin was famous as the most beautiful woman in Koshu, and Princess Matsu herself was also famous for her beauty along with her sister Princess Kiku (lawful wife of Kagekatsu UESUGI).

Princess Matsu's mother Aburakawafujin was famous as the most beautiful woman in Koshu, and Princess Matsu herself was also famous for her beauty along with her sister Princess Kiku (lawful wife of Kagekatsu UESUGI).

sen.j: 松姫のもうひとりの姉真竜院の母も油川夫人とする説によると、松姫の同母姉妹は真理姫、菊姫とされる。
sen.e: According to the theory that the mother of Princess Matsu's another older sister Shinryuin was also Fujin Arakawa, Princess Matsu's sisters were Princess Mari and Princess Kiku.
sen.cmt: 用語集では真理姫→Marihime となっていましたが、松姫、菊姫とそろえました。
sen.e: According to the theory that the mother of Princess Matsu's another older sister Shinryuin was also Aburakawafujin, Princess Matsu's sisters were Princess Mari and Princess Kiku.
According to the theory that the mother of Princess Matsu's another older sister Shinryuin was also Aburakawafujin, Princess Matsu's sisters were Princess Mari and Princess Kiku.
